summary: In 2008, stockbroker, investment adviser and financier Bernie Madoff made headlines around the world when he was arrested for perpetrating perhaps the largest financial fraud in U.S. history.

reviews.content: The Netflix docuseries (2023) tells a much better and engaging story. IMO, this movie placed emphasis on the wrong parts.

The 2016 mini-series "Madoff" with Richard Dreyfus is SO much better. This one is fine, but pretty shallow and not very revealing. Dreyfuss plays Madoff completely differently from DeNiro, and in my opinion, much better.

Touching film drama that takes an interesting angle focusing on the destruction that Bernie Madoff's Ponzi scheme caused within in his own family. Excellent acting performances by Robert De Niro and Michelle Pfeiffer. Regarding the fraud itself, it raises more questions than it answers and shows the complete lack of oversight from the regulating authorities.

‘The Wizard of Lies' is obviously determined to make Bernie Madoff look like, in Mark Baum's immortal words, an incredibly big piece of s**t; a manipulative, self-absorbed sociopath, a point that it hammers home with the final, slightly heavy-handed bit of dialogue and lingering shot. It desperately wants to be an intriguing character study, and with Robert De Niro at the helm and Michelle Pfeiffer in support – both do fantastic work and carry the film on their backs -- it probably should have been. However, after all is said and done, there's no getting around how incredibly dry and disappointingly uninteresting it is considering who's involved.

The Wizard of Lies deals mainly with the aftermath once the scandal broke.  If you're interested in the much more interesting story on how Madoff rose to prominence and perpetrated his scandal I recommend the ABC miniseries Madoff.  Moreover, I think Richard Dreyfuss gave a better performance as Madoff than De Niro.
Leaves long-answered questions too open for my taste, but an interesting exploration nonetheless.  3.9/5

If you're looking for answers, here's your spoiler: you're not going to get a lot of answers. Madoff was a greedy bastard and a first-class sociopath.
And De Niro does sociopaths well.
This was very informative. Robert Deniro was the perfect casting choice. It is a very long movie so make sure you have time to finish it all. I definitely recommend though.  Worth the watch!
You could simply not make this story up.  A must-see for anyone trusting their money to charming financial advisors.
A really good performance good story

Watch it. It's a good way to spend a couple of hours. PROS: DeNiro is perfect... as usual. So is all the cast. It's interesting to see how the rich and famous party... and that beneath their wealth the families may not be really happy. CONS: We see why one of Madoff's kids killed himself. But the big question that is never answered is: WHY did a rich and successful man like Madoff start a fraud? He already was rich and successful. Why? How could the great talent behind the script fail to include a flashback or two to Madoff's childhood to explain his motivation? Were his parents terrible? Nevertheless, it's very watchable.

Terrible, looking for more on start of Ponzi scheme, never shown! Okay so at end tell where things stand today, no. I stopped liking De Niro a long time ago. Tried this movie anyway, writers took what could have been a great movie and ruined it.

Look, it's not a wonder, it's normal. It doesn't clarify anything about Bernie's multi-million dollar theft, it leaves things the same as they are today. Where did you hide the more than 50 billion dollars, Bernie?
It was really good. Never knew the power of wallstreet. I mean people focus on the wrong people...
Not believable. At the end of the day I cannot buy the story. The acting is incredibly old. There are so many better options.

For me personally, this was a very interesting movie. I hadn't heard of this event before because I was a bit too young when it happened I guess. The Wallstreet world is very interesting and complicated, and I find it to be quite Intriguing. This movie is a bit of an inside in this financial world, even though it's not a very positive story.

The storyline itself was very well done, and so was the acting. Robert De Niro was brilliant, you could see that he got frustrated once someone asked him about his work, because he was keeping this huge secret for everyone, and it started taking its toll. He could be so friendly to people, but then he would just snap to the people who are closest to him. De Niro did a very good job.

I don't really understand why they decided to go with the "we-tell-the-story-through-an-interview" type of storyline because I didn't really know who the woman was that interviewed him, and we didn't get to know a lot about her or her work. So that's still a bit vague for me. Apart from that, a very interesting and well-done film I would for sure recommend!
Another worthless De Nero Movie.  You need to retire.
Although the plot was great, the movie lagged after about an hour or so. The movie just got more and more depressing as I watched.

The spectacular fall of financial fraudster Bernie Madoff, were mind-boggling. People casually wrote cheques for $10? million. A $250?million investment was called "small change". Madoff's Ponzi scheme defrauded his clients of $65?billion. His eventual jail sentence of 150 years was pretty mind-boggling too.
The story reveals itself as vignettes that become more and more tight toward the end. How psychopathy has a huge blind spot.
Pray God gives him the fruit of his lips! Evil he is!
[The Wizard of Lies] achieves its greatest power as a character study.
Didnt care about the characters. DeNiros performance was boring

Captivating portrayal of an epic historical financial fraud. Awesome cast playing difficult characters. Family commitments held together by excessive wealth, lies and deception. What a life. Tragic betrayal.
It had enough good parts to say it was decent, but I can’t imagine anyone watching this more than once.
Loved it! Michelle and Robert did wonders with this film.

One of the better Madoff movies (it shows the aftermath instead of during his scheming), but seriously, haven't we heard and seen enough of this guy already?  I don't think we should popularize some guy who cheated people out of millions of dollars. The only thing that really made this movie OK was the cast (De Niro, Pfeifer).  I feel like the TV series "Madoff" showed mostly all of what was in this movie, although not in depth as much.

Not nearly as good as ABC's mini series Madoff.  But still gets a passing grade due to it's high impact cast and solid direction.  The true story does little in the way of shedding new light on this much discussed topic.

super boring and pointless. finished it reluctantly on 2.0 speed while half-watching lol. the only reason i watched this was because i was curious about the details of the bernie madoff scheme and how it all happened. turns out this movie was barely about that. there was some info here and there, but it was mostly about after he got caught, what he went through, how it affected his relationship with his family, how it affected his family, all of their emotions and feelings. does it seem like i care about any of that garbage? gtfoh (1 viewing)
Strong performances make this fact based drama enjoyable viewing even if it doesnt tell the viewer anything new
A great movie explaining the effecs of Bernie's actions had on his family
I liked the visuals and performances were fine.
Too much drama and less about the story. They try to idolise the man and yet the man portrayed was not relatable. Did not enjoy it and shut it midway.

Good story telling. Fine acting. This piece focuses on the intimate relationships of the Madoff family and how they played out after Bernie confessed to his sons. Only one scene clunked in the film, that of Bernie's cohort in crime joking at great length about "pussies". Not needed, and thrown in for no reason at all.

Excellent - excellent - excellent - I have seen this show about four times and I still tend to find something that I did not notice before! I adore De Niro's inhabiting the character and making it his own and I have a whole new found respect for Michelle Pfeiffer - her acting is top notch!
this is just noting...noting to watch,noting...time wasting

This is a mesmerizing film, with a great De Niro and an excellent Pfeiffer.  I enjoyed it and recommend it.  Afterwards, we can ask whether the film portray's Bernie correctly or not, but ultimately we need to hear from the experts to know the answer to that question.  This film is basically a family drama, but it is based on Bernie's story that he was a legit guy who made one fatal decision, to cover up losses in the 2008 recession, and who could never recover.
Painful period brilliantly retold
In 2008, stockbroker, investment adviser and financier Bernie Madoff made headlines around the world when he was arrested for perpetrating perhaps the largest financial fraud in U.S. history.

Unsettling, but properly-so. Some talent is wasted in the understated performances, but not so much that it detracts from the movie as a whole. Frankly though, DeNiro was fantastic, but the underrated performance here is Pfeiffer.
Very good film but complex for me to follow and understand
bland recreation of a horrible man/event. Maybe they didn't get much personal info?
perfect title for the wizard of liberal lies
Definitely an interesting story and the impacts it had on his family. I thought DeNiro and Pfeiffer were excellent. Madoff deserves the worst punishment we can think of.

The Wizard of Lies: This HBO biopic delves into  the 2008 arrest of Wall Street conman Bernie Madoff, perpetrator of the largest Ponzi scheme in U.S. history, and its fallout on family members and business associates. Robert DeNiro and Michelle Pfeiffer are both excellent as the calculating scam artist who charmed more than 64 billion dollars out of investors and his wife who says she was unaware of the scheme, but given its epic scale and the thousands of investors ruined as a result, the treatment by director Barry Levinson (Rain Man, Good Morning Vietnam) oddly sympathetic tone towards Madoff's wife and sons. B

It's great to see legendary actors like De Niro and Pfeiffer at the top of their game. Despite criticism that the film attempts to make Madoff sympathetic, De Niro imbues that character with a blank gaze that is chilling. The question is posed and answered in the film: He is indeed a sociopath.
I thought this was just alright. DeNiro and Michelle P. were great but otherwise the acting was bland. It kept my attention but wasn't anything special, ok for an HBO film.

Straight forward biopic of Wall Street investor Bernie Madoff who defrauded his clients of over 50 Billion dollars. Robert De Niro is stellar as Madoff in the title role but the film feels a bit flat as the drama doesn't really have any hidden secrets. Madoff is an unsympathetic character and the film doesn't really shed a lot of light on why he did what he did except that he made mistakes and was ultimately caught. A good history lesson but not compelling viewing.
4 types of pussy description. perfect!

Pretty good movie. Though it covers incredibly familiar and well-covered ground in the Madoff story, it's still compelling to watch thanks to its strong direction from Levinson and great performances from De Niro, Pfeiffer and Nivola.
Fastidious and longer than it should, The Wizard of Lies can't be saved even with Robert De Niro's and Michelle Pfeiffer's stunning performances.
Interesting but missing something

Outstanding acting and directing highlight this fact based story of the financial  crime of the century.  One just has to decide which actor played a better Madoff...Richard Dreyfuss or Robert De Niro?
1/2 Shakespearean tragedy, 1/2 history lesson, this is more compelling than the trailers make it look. It's not really a family, party, or date movie, but it's good nonetheless.
If this film is indeed a true depiction of "Bernie" Madoff, then he is indeed a sociopath.

I liked this movie though I wanted more numbers/facts about the actual events.  I liked the commentary on our financial/political system.  It was a little long, but the acting and the story were both well done.
Interestingly twisted but not completely engrossing. Shocking this actually happened.
De Niro is a has been.  Good script.  Bad acting.
great performances. crazy story.
Amazing cast, slow movie poorly directed I'm assuming!
De Niro is true icon, emulating a man in Bernie Madoff so perfectly and masterfully that at moments, you forget you are watching a Hollywood rendition of a notorious historical scandal.
Very disappointing. Good cast but poor direction of an interesting story. Frequent flashbacks totally destroy any sense of suspense
De Niro is in top form here but the supporting actors simply cannot carry the scenes he isn't in.
Gawd, I hate the financially rich. Its all rigged & they're all thieves therefore. This movie sapped the last drip of sympathy for them or empathy with them.

De Niro again shows why he is a great actor - he's totally believable. Michelle Feiffer and the rest of the cast give you a great sense of New York's dog-eat-dog hectic atmosphere. And the thick as mud Noo Yawk accents remind you that you're not in Kansas anymore.
It was hard to watch Madoff curse at his sons, yet they still loved him (before they knew what he did). When they asked him how he traded stocks, he angrily told them, "You run your business and I'll run mine". What an asshole.
Mostly, I came away with Madoff's refusing to accept responsibility. He blames investors for being greedy. He never thought about how he would ruin lives if his scheme collapsed. He says, "My problem is that I like to please people". Bullshit. He likes ADORATION from people. He never gives a shit about the effect of his fraud on their lives. (hmmm... sounds like a president I read about lol).
The tragedy is the suicide of one of his sons. Even if he's got sociopathic tendencies (it's never stated if he did) that's gotta rip your heart to shreds.
This is a fine movie from fine people and a great character study of "the banality of evil". I get the feeling that if I ever met Bernie in his early days, I would have thought: nice, smart guy, but too fucking crude for my taste. I thoroughly enjoyed  this movie.

Robert DeNiro is excellent and some good scenes saved this movie from being completely unwatchable. But the greatest problem of this movie is its exaggeratedly subjetive approach. Both the movie which the movie is based on and the screenplay made the Bernie Madoff sort of a poor little kid in the middle of his own shit. It's not a good biopic because it constantly forces the audience to accept an ideia that most of the people will not accept. A biopic like this must give a chance to the audience to develop a personal opinion, not to force them into "swallowing" one.
A devastating tragedy with an immense return-to-form performance from De Niro.

DeNiro's made so many awful movies in recent years you forget our tremendous an actor he can be. And with the great Barry Levinson at the helm and Michelle Pfeiffer putting in a stellar performance, this film is well worth seeing in spite of already knowing much of how things tragically turn out.
Dreadfully poorly done, Script is crap. Every time RD opens his mouth, you wish it was Richard Dreyfus,  Go watch him.

Wizard of Lies is based on the Madoff fraudulent orchestration and demise his family.  Sadly he lost both of his sons one to cancer and the other committed suicide.  Madoff was either masterful wizard of stealing other people's money or fabulously delusional.  Robert DeNiro acted much like Goodfellas character but he seemed as if people should have felt sorry for him.  Overall it was a great history lesson to all those who think could get away from stealing other people's money.  One thing is for certain Madoff is much like any serial killer but in his case he is a mastermind of people's money.

Oh, the poor family who lived luxurious lives with other people's money.  This movie focuses on the Madoffs and how they suffered from the fathers heartless theft.  What about all the people who lost everything.  Poor Ruth was left alone with just a few million dollars while everyone else got nothing!

Don't bother watching if you have any interest in finance or the actual fraud that took place. This movie is simply a weak exploration of some of the family interactions that supposedly took place between Bernie and his wife and children. A story about family dynamics, not a story about his success/fraud.

Amazing performances. Wonderful screenplay. Dead-on direction. I was totally captivated by Robert "Bob" De Niro's performance as well as Michelle Pfiffer & Alessandro Nivola's. At this point, I must read Diana Henriques book. I truly recommend watching this version as shown on HBO. Mr. De Niro not only captured the full essence of the character he portrayed, Bernard L. Madoff, he utterly made this role his own. To date, I believe this is one of his most stellar performances. Michelle Pfeiffer as Ruth Maloff was completely convincing. Giving us a glimpse of the life of a shattered wife. Ms. Pfeiffer has been one of my absolute favorite actresses since Grease 2. Alessandro Nivola stole the film to me, however. With his EPIC performance as Mark Madoff. Truly depicting the torment of an outcast pushed to his limits. If these three are not nominated for some kind of an award... I will start an Internet protest! Amazing film. Kudos to Barry Levinson for such a brilliant work on creating the Bernie Madoff story, The Wizard of Lies. On a scale of 1-10... I rate this movie a 12.
wish it focused on the actual corruption itself a little more, but a solid watch on a boring Wednesday.
Fine performances by DeNiro and Pfeiffer head up an ensemble cast in this portrayal of Ponzi-schemer Bernie Madoff. Thoroughly fascinating and infuriating.

The story of Bernie Madoff (played by Robert De Niro), the man responsible for the largest Ponzi scheme in history, defrauding investors out of approximately $65 bn. 

Heaps of potential - I was expecting something along the lines of Enron - The Smartest Guys In the Room, but dramatized.  However, this doesn't come close to living up to it.  

This movie could have been a great exposition on what drives people to commit crimes of such a magnitude, especially a person who was once the paragon of ethics and prudence and who was revered in his industry.  Just the transition from law-abiding citizen to master criminal would have been fascinating to watch, not to mention how he put his criminal plans into operation.

But, no, nothing like that.  No transition and very little on the criminal operation.  The focus is almost entirely on Madoff and his family during the trial and his incarceration.  While the wife and children deserve our empathy, by focusing on the private life of Bernie Madoff he is made out to be more of a victim than a villain, which is a preposterous thought.  

Thus there is very little engagement, as the central character is certainly not worth supporting.  This generally makes for a fairly flat experience.  

There are some interesting intrigues and sub-plots and these are tellingly felt in the last few scenes, as Madoff's crimes impact his family.  

Overall: watchable, but could have been so much better.

DeNiro as Madoff was mesmerizing. His rationalizations and self-justifications (mentioned a couple of times) fills out a picture. I didn't like the jailhouse interview device, rarely do, and would have liked a closer look at just how he pulled this off. Oh, and Hank Azaria is always wonderful.

Couldn't wait to see this as the subject matter had always interested and infuriated me. This was boring and full of the laziest choices possible. This looked like it was made by people who don't want to have to try very hard.

Wizard of Lies was pure torture.  It opens to a jail interview then goes back to the story.  The whole thing was boring, skipped around victimizing his family, rather than the real victims, his clients.  And what the heck were those special effects when he was I don't know...hallucinations, visions, flashbacks? It was like something from a cheap movie in the 60's.  After not seeing Michelle Pfeifer in so many years I found her also unconvincing. I can't figure it out....the script or her acting?  Was this supposed to be about his family?  I really don't think that with the multitudes of lives that were completely destroyed by Madoff that the details of his family are even important.  So disappointed in a hugely hyped movie and unimpressed by HBO's effort in what should have been more impressive.
One of Barry Levinson's stronger efforts.  Does a good job of managing character motivations and tension through flashback and non-linear narratives.  All of the actors were excellent.
DeNiro should retire he looks old and tired and that is all I see when I look at reviews of him now. An old man that should be in a nursing home, like my grandfather. Michelle is an okay actress.
